Description: Pottery jug. Wheel-made; depressed globular body, carinated shoulder and lower body with straight sides; flat bottom with ring base; narrow tubular neck (slightly concave) with a rounded, everted rim; short arched handle, joining the body below the rim. No description of clay or slip has survived.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Roemer and Pelizaeus Museum, Hildesheim. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel from Salamis tomb (GR 1982,0729.59), dated 1st century AD Roman, with a Cypriot or Levantine production place. Seems to be a Eastern Sigillata ware (Hayes Form 108) jug,. or could be a red or black slipped copy.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (IF.133)
